        #include <stdio.h>
        #include <string.h>
        #include <stdlib.h>

        int main() {
            int A, B;
            scanf("%d %d", &A, &B);

            // Step1: 
            int x = A - 2 * B;
            if (x < 0) x = 0;

            // Step2: convert x to string
            char s[21]; // 20 digits and null terminator
            sprintf(s, "%d", x);
            int len_s = strlen(s);

            // Build t: 
            char t[21]; // worst-case: same length as s? or shorter? we allocate same length plus one for safety.
            int t_index = 0;
            int i = 0;
            while (i < len_s) {
                if (s[i] == 'A') {
                    t[t_index++] = 'A';
                    i++;
                } else if (s[i] == 'B') {
                    if (i+1 < len_s && s[i+1] == 'C') {
                        t[t_index++] = 'D';
                        i += 2;
                    } else {
                        t[t_index++] = 'X';
                        i++;
                    }
                } else {
                    t[t_index++] = 'X';
                    i++;
                }
            }
            t[t_index] = '\0'; // null terminate

            // Now count total from t
            int total = 0;
            int numA = 0;
            for (int j = 0; j < t_index; j++) {
                if (t[j] == 'X') {
                    numA = 0;
                } else if (t[j] == 'A') {
                    numA++;
                } else if (t[j] == 'D') {
                    total += numA;
                }
            }

            // Step3: 
            // The third program: we are going to create an array of integers from the string that would be input? 
            // But we know the input to the third program is the string representation of total? 
            // However, the third program does: 
            //   tokens = input().split()
            //   ABC = [int(token) for token in tokens]
            // But we are not going to convert total to string and then back to int? We have total as an integer.
            // And the tokens are one token: the string of total? 
            // But the third program then uses the list of integers.

            // We are going to simulate the third program: 
            //   We have one integer: total.
            //   So the array ABC has one element: total.
            int count5 = 0;
            int ABC[1] = {total};
            for (int i = 0; i < 1; i++) {
                if (ABC[i] == 5) {
                    count5++;
                }
            }
            if (count5 == 2) {
                int s = 0;
                for (int i = 0; i < 1; i++) {
                    s += ABC[i];
                }
                if (s == 17) {
                    printf("YES\n");
                } else {
                    printf("NO\n");
                }
            } else {
                printf("NO\n");
            }

            return 0;
        }
